api_key.description: (Required unless validate is false) Datadog API key. This can also be set via the DD_API_KEY environment variable.

api_url.description: The API URL. This can also be set via the DD_HOST environment variable. Note that this URL must not end with the /api/ path. For example, https://api.datadoghq.com/ is a correct value, while https://api.datadoghq.com/api/ is not. And if you're working with "EU" version of Datadog, use https://api.datadoghq.eu/.

app_key.description: (Required unless validate is false) Datadog APP key. This can also be set via the DD_APP_KEY environment variable.

http_client_retry_enabled.description: Enables request retries on HTTP status codes 429 and 5xx.

http_client_retry_timeout.description: The HTTP request retry timeout period.

validate.description: Enables validation of the provided API and APP keys during provider initialization. Default is true. When false, api_key and app_key won't be checked.

active.description: When true indicates this downtime is being actively applied

monitor_id.description: When specified, this downtime will only apply to this monitor

scope.description: specify the group scope to which this downtime applies. For everything use '*'

start.description: Specify when this downtime should start

start_date.description: String representing date and time to start the downtime in RFC3339 format.

timezone.description: The timezone for the downtime, default UTC

period.description: How often to repeat as an integer. For example to repeat every 3 days, select a `type` of `days` and a `period` of `3`.

rrule.description: The RRULE standard for defining recurring events. For example, to have a recurring event on the first day of each month, use `FREQ=MONTHLY;INTERVAL=1`. Most common rrule options from the iCalendar Spec are supported. Attributes specifying the duration in RRULE are not supported (for example, `DTSTART`, `DTEND`, `DURATION`).

type.description: One of `days`, `weeks`, `months`, or `years`

until_date.description: The date at which the recurrence should end as a POSIX timestamp. `until_occurrences` and `until_date` are mutually exclusive.

until_occurrences.description: How many times the downtime will be rescheduled. `until_occurrences` and `until_date` are mutually exclusive.

week_days.description: A list of week days to repeat on. Choose from: `Mon`, `Tue`, `Wed`, `Thu`, `Fri`, `Sat` or `Sun`. Only applicable when `type` is `weeks`. First letter must be capitalized.

Wildcards, such as `?` (for single characters) and `*` (for multiple characters) can also be used. Only hosts that match one of the defined tags will be imported into Datadog. The rest will be ignored. Host matching a given tag can also be excluded by adding `!` before the tag. e.x. `env:production,instance-type:c1.*,!region:us-east-1`.

Each `datadog_logs_custom_pipeline` resource defines a complete pipeline. The order of the pipelines is maintained in a different resource: `datadog_logs_pipeline_order`. When creating a new pipeline, you need to **explicitly** add this pipeline to the `datadog_logs_pipeline_order` resource to track the pipeline. Similarly, when a pipeline needs to be destroyed, remove its references from the `datadog_logs_pipeline_order` resource.

daily_limit.description: The number of log events you can send in this index per day before you are rate-limited.

disable_daily_limit.description: If true, sets the daily_limit value to null and the index is not limited on a daily basis (any specified daily_limit value in the request is ignored). If false or omitted, the index's current daily_limit is maintained.

**Note:** It is not possible to delete logs indexes through Terraform, so an index remains in your account after the resource is removed from your terraform config. Reach out to support to delete a logs index.

block.description: Provides a Datadog Logs Pipeline API resource to manage the integrations. Integration pipelines are the pipelines that are automatically installed for your organization when sending the logs with specific sources. You don't need to maintain or update these types of pipelines. Keeping them as resources, however, allows you to manage the order of your pipelines by referencing them in your `datadog_logs_pipeline_order` resource. If you don't need the `pipeline_order` feature, this resource declaration can be omitted.

Provides a Datadog metric tag configuration resource. This can be used to modify tag configurations for metrics.

enable_logs_sample.description: A boolean indicating whether or not to include a list of log values which triggered the alert. This is only used by log monitors. Defaults to `false`.

escalation_message.description: A message to include with a re-notification. Supports the `@username` notification allowed elsewhere.

evaluation_delay.description:
(Only applies to metric alert) Time (in seconds) to delay evaluation, as a non-negative integer.

For example, if the value is set to `300` (5min), the `timeframe` is set to `last_5m` and the time is 7:00, the monitor will evaluate data from 6:50 to 6:55. This is useful for AWS CloudWatch and other backfilled metrics to ensure the monitor will always have data during evaluation.

force_delete.description: A boolean indicating whether this monitor can be deleted even if its referenced by other resources (e.g. SLO, composite monitor).

groupby_simple_monitor.description: Whether or not to trigger one alert if any source breaches a threshold. This is only used by log monitors. Defaults to `false`.

include_tags.description: A boolean indicating whether notifications from this monitor automatically insert its triggering tags into the title. Defaults to `true`.

locked.description: A boolean indicating whether changes to this monitor should be restricted to the creator or admins. Defaults to `false`.

message.description:
A message to include with notifications for this monitor.

Email notifications can be sent to specific users by using the same `@username` notation as events.

name.description: Name of Datadog monitor.

new_group_delay.description:
The time (in seconds) to skip evaluations for new groups.

`new_group_delay` overrides `new_host_delay` if it is set to a nonzero value.

new_host_delay.description: **Deprecated**. See `new_group_delay`. Time (in seconds) to allow a host to boot and applications to fully start before starting the evaluation of monitor results. Should be a non-negative integer. This value is ignored for simple monitors and monitors not grouped by host. Defaults to `300`. The only case when this should be used is to override the default and set `new_host_delay` to zero for monitors grouped by host. **Deprecated.** Use `new_group_delay` except when setting `new_host_delay` to zero.

no_data_timeframe.description:
The number of minutes before a monitor will notify when data stops reporting. Provider defaults to 10 minutes.

We recommend at least 2x the monitor timeframe for metric alerts or 2 minutes for service checks.

notify_audit.description: A boolean indicating whether tagged users will be notified on changes to this monitor. Defaults to `false`.

notify_no_data.description: A boolean indicating whether this monitor will notify when data stops reporting. Defaults to `false`.

priority.description: Integer from 1 (high) to 5 (low) indicating alert severity.

query.description:
The monitor query to notify on. Note this is not the same query you see in the UI and the syntax is different depending on the monitor type, please see the [API Reference](https://docs.datadoghq.com/api/v1/monitors/#create-a-monitor) for details. `terraform plan` will validate query contents unless `validate` is set to `false`.

**Note:** APM latency data is now available as Distribution Metrics. Existing monitors have been migrated automatically but all terraformed monitors can still use the existing metrics. We strongly recommend updating monitor definitions to query the new metrics. To learn more, or to see examples of how to update your terraform definitions to utilize the new distribution metrics, see the [detailed doc](https://docs.datadoghq.com/tracing/guide/ddsketch_trace_metrics/).

renotify_interval.description: The number of minutes after the last notification before a monitor will re-notify on the current status. It will only re-notify if it's not resolved.

renotify_occurrences.description: The number of re-notification messages that should be sent on the current status.

renotify_statuses.description: The types of statuses for which re-notification messages should be sent. Valid values are `alert`, `warn`, `no data`.

require_full_window.description:
A boolean indicating whether this monitor needs a full window of data before it's evaluated.

We highly recommend you set this to `false` for sparse metrics, otherwise some evaluations will be skipped. Default: `true` for `on average`, `at all times` and `in total` aggregation. `false` otherwise.

tags.description: A list of tags to associate with your monitor. This can help you categorize and filter monitors in the manage monitors page of the UI. Note: it's not currently possible to filter by these tags when querying via the API

timeout_h.description: The number of hours of the monitor not reporting data before it will automatically resolve from a triggered state.

type.description: The type of the monitor. The mapping from these types to the types found in the Datadog Web UI can be found in the Datadog API [documentation page](https://docs.datadoghq.com/api/v1/monitors/#create-a-monitor). Note: The monitor type cannot be changed after a monitor is created. Valid values are `composite`, `event alert`, `log alert`, `metric alert`, `process alert`, `query alert`, `rum alert`, `service check`, `synthetics alert`, `trace-analytics alert`, `slo alert`, `event-v2 alert`, `audit alert`, `ci-pipelines alert`, `error-tracking alert`.

validate.description: If set to `false`, skip the validation call done during plan.

recovery_window.description: Describes how long an anomalous metric must be normal before the alert recovers.

trigger_window.description: Describes how long a metric must be anomalous before an alert triggers.

block.description: A mapping containing `recovery_window` and `trigger_window` values, e.g. `last_15m` . Can only be used for, and are required for, anomaly monitors.

critical.description: The monitor `CRITICAL` threshold. Must be a number.

critical_recovery.description: The monitor `CRITICAL` recovery threshold. Must be a number.

ok.description: The monitor `OK` threshold. Must be a number.

unknown.description: The monitor `UNKNOWN` threshold. Must be a number.

warning.description: The monitor `WARNING` threshold. Must be a number.

warning_recovery.description: The monitor `WARNING` recovery threshold. Must be a number.

delay.description: Delay between each key stroke for a "type test" step.

element.description: Element to use for the step, json encoded string.

email.description: Details of the email for an "assert email" step.

files.description: Details of the files for an "upload files" step, json encoded string.

modifiers.description: Modifier to use for a "press key" step.

playing_tab_id.description: ID of the tab to play the subtest.

subtest_public_id.description: ID of the Synthetics test to use as subtest.

block.description: Custom user selector to use for the step.

name.description: Name of the extracted variable.

block.description: Details of the variable to extract.
Parameters for the step.
Steps for browser tests.

id.description: ID of the global variable to use. This is actually only used (and required) in the case of using a variable of type `global`.

name.description: Name of the variable.

type.description: Type of browser test variable. Valid values are `element`, `email`, `global`, `javascript`, `text`.

block.description: Variables used for a browser test steps. Multiple `variable` blocks are allowed with the structure below.

id.description: When type = `global`, ID of the global variable to use.

name.description: Name of the variable.

type.description: Type of test configuration variable. Valid values are `global`, `text`.

block.description: Variables used for the test configuration. Multiple `config_variable` blocks are allowed with the structure below.

accept_self_signed.description: For SSL test, whether or not the test should allow self signed certificates.

allow_insecure.description: Allows loading insecure content for an HTTP test.

check_certificate_revocation.description: For SSL test, whether or not the test should fail on revoked certificate in stapled OCSP.

follow_redirects.description: Determines whether or not the API HTTP test should follow redirects.

min_failure_duration.description: Minimum amount of time in failure required to trigger an alert. Default is `0`.

min_location_failed.description: Minimum number of locations in failure required to trigger an alert. Default is `1`.

monitor_name.description: The monitor name is used for the alert title as well as for all monitor dashboard widgets and SLOs.

no_screenshot.description: Prevents saving screenshots of the steps.

tick_every.description: How often the test should run (in seconds).

count.description: Number of retries needed to consider a location as failed before sending a notification alert.

interval.description: Interval between a failed test and the next retry in milliseconds.

type.description: Type of basic authentication to use when performing the test.

block.description: The HTTP basic authentication credentials. Exactly one nested block is allowed with the structure below.
Client certificate to use when performing the test request. Exactly one nested block is allowed with the structure below.

dns_server.description: DNS server to use for DNS tests (`subtype = "dns"`).

dns_server_port.description: DNS server port to use for DNS tests.

host.description: Host name to perform the test with.

message.description: For UDP and websocket tests, message to send with the request.

method.description: The HTTP method. Valid values are `GET`, `POST`, `PATCH`, `PUT`, `DELETE`, `HEAD`, `OPTIONS`.

no_saving_response_body.description: Determines whether or not to save the response body.

number_of_packets.description: Number of pings to use per test for ICMP tests (`subtype = "icmp"`) between 0 and 10.

port.description: Port to use when performing the test.

servername.description: For SSL tests, it specifies on which server you want to initiate the TLS handshake, allowing the server to present one of multiple possible certificates on the same IP address and TCP port number.

should_track_hops.description: This will turn on a traceroute probe to discover all gateways along the path to the host destination. For ICMP tests (`subtype = "icmp"`).

timeout.description: Timeout in seconds for the test. Defaults to `60`.

url.description: The URL to send the request to.

block.description: Required if `type = "api"`. The synthetics test request.

url.description: URL of the proxy to perform the test.

block.description: The proxy to perform the test.
Provides a Datadog synthetics test resource. This can be used to create and manage Datadog synthetics test.

name.description: Name for user.

roles.description: A list a role IDs to assign to the user.

send_user_invitation.description: Whether an invitation email should be sent when the user is created.

user_invitation_id.description: The ID of the user invitation that was sent when creating the user.

verified.description: Returns `true` if the user is verified.

block.description: Provides a Datadog user resource. This can be used to create and manage Datadog users.

custom_headers.description: The headers attached to the webhook.

block.description: Provides a Datadog webhook resource. This can be used to create and manage Datadog webhooks.

is_secret.description: Whether the custom variable is secret or not.

name.description: The name of the variable. It corresponds with `<CUSTOM_VARIABLE_NAME>`.

value.description: The value of the custom variable.

block.description: Provides a Datadog webhooks custom variable resource. This can be used to create and manage Datadog webhooks custom variables.

key.description: The value of the API Key.

agents_ipv4.description: An Array of IPv4 addresses in CIDR format specifying the A records for the Agent endpoint.

agents_ipv6.description: An Array of IPv6 addresses in CIDR format specifying the A records for the Agent endpoint.

api_ipv4.description: An Array of IPv4 addresses in CIDR format specifying the A records for the API endpoint.

api_ipv6.description: An Array of IPv6 addresses in CIDR format specifying the A records for the API endpoint.

apm_ipv4.description: An Array of IPv4 addresses in CIDR format specifying the A records for the APM endpoint.

apm_ipv6.description: An Array of IPv6 addresses in CIDR format specifying the A records for the APM endpoint.

logs_ipv4.description: An Array of IPv4 addresses in CIDR format specifying the A records for the Logs endpoint.

logs_ipv6.description: An Array of IPv6 addresses in CIDR format specifying the A records for the Logs endpoint.

process_ipv4.description: An Array of IPv4 addresses in CIDR format specifying the A records for the Process endpoint.

process_ipv6.description: An Array of IPv6 addresses in CIDR format specifying the A records for the Process endpoint.

synthetics_ipv4.description: An Array of IPv4 addresses in CIDR format specifying the A records for the Synthetics endpoint.

synthetics_ipv4_by_location.description: A map of IPv4 prefixes (string of concatenated IPs, delimited by ',') by location.

synthetics_ipv6.description: An Array of IPv6 addresses in CIDR format specifying the A records for the Synthetics endpoint.

synthetics_ipv6_by_location.description: A map of IPv6 prefixes (string of concatenated IPs, delimited by ',') by location.

webhooks_ipv4.description: An Array of IPv4 addresses in CIDR format specifying the A records for the Webhooks endpoint.

webhooks_ipv6.description: An Array of IPv6 addresses in CIDR format specifying the A records for the Webhooks endpoint.

block.description: Use this data source to retrieve information about Datadog's IP addresses.
Use this data source to list several existing logs indexes for use in other resources.

index_names.description: Array of strings identifying by their name(s) the index(es) of your organization. Logs are tested against the query filter of each index one by one, following the order of the array. Logs are eventually stored in the first matching index.

block.description: Get the current order of your log indexes.

enable_logs_sample.description: Whether or not a list of log values which triggered the alert is included. This is only used by log monitors.

escalation_message.description: Message included with a re-notification for this monitor.

evaluation_delay.description: Time (in seconds) for which evaluation is delayed. This is only used by metric monitors.

groupby_simple_monitor.description: Whether or not to trigger one alert if any source breaches a threshold.

include_tags.description: Whether or not notifications from the monitor automatically inserts its triggering tags into the title.

locked.description: Whether or not changes to the monitor are restricted to the creator or admins.

message.description: Message included with notifications for this monitor

monitor_tags_filter.description: A list of monitor tags to limit the search. This filters on the tags set on the monitor itself.

monitor_threshold_windows.description: Mapping containing `recovery_window` and `trigger_window` values, e.g. `last_15m`. This is only used by anomaly monitors.

name.description: Name of the monitor

name_filter.description: A monitor name to limit the search.

new_group_delay.description: Time (in seconds) to skip evaluations for new groups.

new_host_delay.description: Time (in seconds) allowing a host to boot and applications to fully start before starting the evaluation of monitor results.

no_data_timeframe.description: The number of minutes before the monitor notifies when data stops reporting.

notify_audit.description: Whether or not tagged users are notified on changes to the monitor.

notify_no_data.description: Whether or not this monitor notifies when data stops reporting.

renotify_interval.description: The number of minutes after the last notification before the monitor re-notifies on the current status.

renotify_occurrences.description: The number of re-notification messages that should be sent on the current status.

renotify_statuses.description: The types of statuses for which re-notification messages should be sent. Valid values are `alert`, `warn`, `no data`.

require_full_window.description: Whether or not the monitor needs a full window of data before it is evaluated.

tags.description: List of tags associated with the monitor.

tags_filter.description: A list of tags to limit the search. This filters on the monitor scope.

timeout_h.description: Number of hours of the monitor not reporting data before it automatically resolves from a triggered state.

type.description: Type of the monitor.
